This class provides a simple timing engine for running animations which calculate animated values and set them on target objects. More...

class AnimatorInflater

Detailed Description

This class provides a simple timing engine for running animations which calculate animated values and set them on target objects.

There is a single timing pulse that all animations use. It runs in a custom handler to ensure that property changes happen on the UI thread.

By default, ValueAnimator uses non-linear time interpolation, via the AccelerateDecelerateInterpolator class, which accelerates into and decelerates out of an animation. This behavior can be changed by calling ValueAnimator::setInterpolator(ITimeInterpolator*).

 class MyAnimatorUpdateLIstener : public gaia::core::IValueAnimatorUpdateListener {
   private:
       gaia::ui::ImageWidget* mpImageWidget;
   public:
       MyAnimatorUpdateLIstener(gaia::ui::ImageWidget* image_widget) {
           mpImageWidget = image_widget;
       }
       virtual ~MyAnimatorUpdateListener() {
       }
       void onAnimationUpdate(gaia::core::ValueAnimator* animation) {
           float x_value = animation->getFloatAnimatedValue(String("X"));
           float y_value = animation->getFloatAnimatedValue(String("Y"));

           mpImageWidget->setX(x_value);
           mpImageWidget->setY(y_value);

           // We use the same value to set different function.
           mpImageWidget->setRotationX(x_value);
           mpImageWidget->setRotationY(y_value);
       }
 };

 // We set the animation effects in the ImageWidget.
 image_widget = new ImageWidget(this);

 // We use a listener to receive the animated value.
 MyAnimatorUpdateListener* listener =  new MyAnimatorUpdateListener(image_widget);

 // Move Over animation effect.
 PropertyValuesHolder* moveover_pvhX = PropertyValuesHolder::ofFloat(String("X"), 2, 50.0f, 700.0f);
 PropertyValuesHolder* moveover_pvhY = PropertyValuesHolder::ofFloat(String("Y"), 2, 50.0f, 1200.0f);
 // New a ValueAnimator with moveover_pvhX and moveover_pvhY.
 ValueAnimator* value_animator = ValueAnimator::ofPropertyValuesHolder(2, moveover_pvhX, moveover_pvhY);

 // Set the behavior of the animation .
 value_animator->setDuration(2000);
 value_animator->setRepeatCount(ValueAnimator::INFINITE);

Definition at line 74 of file ValueAnimator.h.

Member Enumeration Documentation

anonymous enum

Public constants.

Enumerator:
RESTART 

When the animation reaches the end and repeatCount is INFINITE or a positive value, the animation restarts from the beginning.

REVERSE 

When the animation reaches the end and repeatCount is INFINITE or a positive value, the animation reverses direction on every iteration.

INFINITE 

This value used used with the setRepeatCount(int32_t) property to repeat the animation indefinitely.

Definition at line 92 of file ValueAnimator.h.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

gaia::core::ValueAnimator::ValueAnimator ( )

Creates a new ValueAnimator object.

This default constructor is primarily for use internally; the factory methods which take parameters are more generally useful.

virtual gaia::core::ValueAnimator::~ValueAnimator ( ) [virtual]

Default destructor.

Member Function Documentation

virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::addUpdateListener ( IValueAnimatorUpdateListener *  listener) [virtual]

Adds a listener to the set of listeners that are sent update events through the life of an animation.

This method is called on all listeners for every frame of the animation, after the values for the animation have been calculated.

Parameters:
listenerthe listener to be added to the current set of listeners for this animation.
virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::cancel ( ) [virtual]

Cancels the animation.

Unlike end(), cancel() causes the animation to stop in its tracks, sending an gaia::core::IAnimatorListener::onAnimationCancel(Animator*) to its listeners, followed by an gaia::core::IAnimatorListener::onAnimationEnd(Animator*) message.

This method must be called on the thread that is running the animation.

Reimplemented from gaia::core::Animator.

virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::end ( ) [virtual]

Ends the animation.

This causes the animation to assign the end value of the property being animated, then calling the IAnimatorListener::onAnimationEnd(Animator*)} method on its listeners.

This method must be called on the thread that is running the animation.

Reimplemented from gaia::core::Animator.

virtual float gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getAnimatedFraction ( ) [virtual]

Returns the current animation fraction, which is the elapsed/interpolated fraction used in the most recent frame update on the animation.

Returns:
Elapsed/interpolated fraction of the animation.
virtual int64_t gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getCurrentPlayTime ( ) [virtual]

Gets the current position of the animation in time, which is equal to the current time minus the time that the animation started.

An animation that is not yet started will return a value of zero.

Returns:
The current position in time of the animation.
virtual int64_t gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getDuration ( ) [virtual]

Gets the length of the animation.

The default duration is 300 milliseconds.

Returns:
The length of the animation, in milliseconds.

Implements gaia::core::Animator.

float gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getFloatAnimatedValue ( )

The most recent value calculated by this ValueAnimator when there is just one property being animated.

This value is only sensible while the animation is running. The main purpose for this read-only property is to retrieve the value from the ValueAnimator during a call to IValueAnimatorUpdateListener::onAnimationUpdate(ValueAnimator), which is called during each animation frame, immediately after the value is calculated.

Returns:
animatedValue The value most recently calculated by this ValueAnimator for the single property being animated. If there are several properties being animated (specified by several PropertyValuesHolder objects in the constructor), this function returns the animated float value for the first of those objects.
float gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getFloatAnimatedValue ( const gaia::base::String &  propertyName)

The most recent value calculated by this ValueAnimator for propertyName.

The main purpose for this read-only property is to retrieve the value from the ValueAnimator during a call to IValueAnimatorUpdateListener::onAnimationUpdate(ValueAnimator), which is called during each animation frame, immediately after the value is calculated.

Returns:
animatedValue The float value most recently calculated for the named property by this ValueAnimator.
static int64_t gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getFrameDelay ( ) [static]

The amount of time, in milliseconds, between each frame of the animation.

This is a requested time that the animation will attempt to honor, but the actual delay between frames may be different, depending on system load and capabilities. This is a static function because the same delay will be applied to all animations, since they are all run off of a single timing loop.

Returns:
the requested time between frames, in milliseconds
int32_t gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getIntAnimatedValue ( )

The most recent value calculated by this ValueAnimator when there is just one property being animated.

This value is only sensible while the animation is running. The main purpose for this read-only property is to retrieve the value from the ValueAnimator during a call to IValueAnimatorUpdateListener::onAnimationUpdate(ValueAnimator), which is called during each animation frame, immediately after the value is calculated.

Returns:
animatedValue The value most recently calculated by this ValueAnimator for the single property being animated. If there are several properties being animated (specified by several PropertyValuesHolder objects in the constructor), this function returns the animated int value for the first of those objects.
int32_t gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getIntAnimatedValue ( const gaia::base::String &  propertyName)

The most recent value calculated by this ValueAnimator for propertyName.

The main purpose for this read-only property is to retrieve the value from the ValueAnimator during a call to IValueAnimatorUpdateListener::onAnimationUpdate(ValueAnimator), which is called during each animation frame, immediately after the value is calculated.

Returns:
animatedValue The int value most recently calculated for the named property by this ValueAnimator.
virtual int32_t gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getRepeatCount ( ) [virtual]

Defines how many times the animation should repeat.

The default value is 0.

Returns:
the number of times the animation should repeat, or INFINITE
virtual int32_t gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getRepeatMode ( ) [virtual]

Defines what this animation should do when it reaches the end.

Returns:
either one of REVERSE or RESTART
virtual int64_t gaia::core::ValueAnimator::getStartDelay ( ) [virtual]

The amount of time, in milliseconds, to delay starting the animation after start() is called.

Returns:
the number of milliseconds to delay running the animation

Implements gaia::core::Animator.

virtual bool gaia::core::ValueAnimator::isRunning ( ) [virtual]

Returns whether this Animator is currently running (having been started and gone past any initial startDelay period and not yet ended).

Returns:
Whether the Animator is running.

Implements gaia::core::Animator.

virtual bool gaia::core::ValueAnimator::isStarted ( ) [virtual]

Returns whether this Animator has been started and not yet ended.

This state is a superset of the state of isRunning(), because an Animator with a nonzero getStartDelay() startDelay will return true for isStarted() during the delay phase, whereas isRunning() will return true only after the delay phase is complete.

Returns:
Whether the Animator has been started and not yet ended.

Reimplemented from gaia::core::Animator.

static ValueAnimator* gaia::core::ValueAnimator::ofFloatN ( int32_t  size,
float  values,
  ... 
) [static]

Constructs and returns a ValueAnimator that animates between float values.

A single value implies that that value is the one being animated to. However, this is not typically useful in a ValueAnimator object because there is no way for the object to determine the starting value for the animation (unlike ObjectAnimator, which can derive that value from the target object and property being animated). Therefore, there should typically be two or more values.

Parameters:
sizeThe number of values.
valuesA set of values that the animation will animate between over time.
Returns:
A ValueAnimator object that is set up to animate between the given values.
static ValueAnimator* gaia::core::ValueAnimator::ofIntN ( int32_t  size,
int32_t  values,
  ... 
) [static]

Constructs and returns a ValueAnimator that animates between int values.

A single value implies that that value is the one being animated to. However, this is not typically useful in a ValueAnimator object because there is no way for the object to determine the starting value for the animation (unlike ObjectAnimator, which can derive that value from the target object and property being animated). Therefore, there should typically be two or more values.

Parameters:
sizeThe number of values.
valuesA set of values that the animation will animate between over time.
Returns:
A ValueAnimator object that is set up to animate between the given values.

PropertyValuesHolder *  values,
  ... 
) [static]

Parameters:
sizeThe number of values.
valuesA set of PropertyValuesHolder objects whose values will be animated between over time.
Returns:
A ValueAnimator object that is set up to animate between the given values.
virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::removeAllUpdateListeners ( ) [virtual]

Removes all listeners from the set listening to frame updates for this animation.

virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::removeUpdateListener ( IValueAnimatorUpdateListener *  listener) [virtual]

Removes a listener from the set listening to frame updates for this animation.

Parameters:
listenerthe listener to be removed from the current set of update listeners for this animation.
virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::reverse ( ) [virtual]

Plays the ValueAnimator in reverse.

If the animation is already running, it will stop itself and play backwards from the point reached when reverse was called. If the animation is not currently running, then it will start from the end and play backwards. This behavior is only set for the current animation; future playing of the animation will use the default behavior of playing forward.

virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setCurrentPlayTime ( int64_t  playTime) [virtual]

Sets the position of the animation to the specified point in time.

This time should be between 0 and the total duration of the animation, including any repetition. If the animation has not yet been started, then it will not advance forward after it is set to this time; it will simply set the time to this value and perform any appropriate actions based on that time. If the animation is already running, then setCurrentPlayTime() will set the current playing time to this value and continue playing from that point.

Parameters:
playTimeThe time, in milliseconds, to which the animation is advanced or rewound.
virtual Animator* gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setDuration ( int64_t  duration) [virtual]

Sets the length of the animation.

The default duration is 300 milliseconds.

Parameters:
durationThe length of the animation, in milliseconds. This value cannot be negative.
Returns:
ValueAnimator The object called with setDuration(). This return value makes it easier to compose statements together that construct and then set the duration, as in ValueAnimator.ofInt(0, 10).setDuration(500).start().

Implements gaia::core::Animator.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ObjectAnimator.

virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setFloatValues ( gaia::base::Vector< float > *  values) [virtual]

Sets float values that will be animated between.

A single value implies that that value is the one being animated to. However, this is not typically useful in a ValueAnimator object because there is no way for the object to determine the starting value for the animation (unlike ObjectAnimator, which can derive that value from the target object and property being animated). Therefore, there should typically be two or more values.

If there are already multiple sets of values defined for this ValueAnimator via more than one PropertyValuesHolder object, this method will set the values for the first of those objects.

Parameters:
valuesA set of values that the animation will animate between over time.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ObjectAnimator.

static void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setFrameDelay ( int64_t  frameDelay) [static]

The amount of time, in milliseconds, between each frame of the animation.

This is a requested time that the animation will attempt to honor, but the actual delay between frames may be different, depending on system load and capabilities. This is a static function because the same delay will be applied to all animations, since they are all run off of a single timing loop.

Parameters:
frameDelaythe requested time between frames, in milliseconds
virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setInterpolator ( ITimeInterpolator *  value) [virtual]

The time interpolator used in calculating the elapsed fraction of this animation.

The interpolator determines whether the animation runs with linear or non-linear motion, such as acceleration and deceleration. The default value is gaia::core::AccelerateDecelerateInterpolator

Parameters:
valuethe interpolator to be used by this animation. A value of null will result in linear interpolation.

Implements gaia::core::Animator.

virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setIntValues ( gaia::base::Vector< int32_t > *  values) [virtual]

Sets int values that will be animated between.

A single value implies that that value is the one being animated to. However, this is not typically useful in a ValueAnimator object because there is no way for the object to determine the starting value for the animation (unlike ObjectAnimator, which can derive that value from the target object and property being animated). Therefore, there should typically be two or more values.

If there are already multiple sets of values defined for this ValueAnimator via more than one PropertyValuesHolder object, this method will set the values for the first of those objects.

Parameters:
valuesA set of values that the animation will animate between over time.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ObjectAnimator.

void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setPointFEvaluator ( IPointFEvaluator *  evaluator)

The PointF evaluator to be used when calculating the animated values of this animation.

A PointF evaluator is a custom evaluator thus use this method to be assigned. If this ValueAnimator has only one set of values being animated between, this evaluator will be used for that set. If there are several sets of values being animated, which is the case if PropertyValuesHOlder objects were set on the ValueAnimator, then the evaluator is assigned just to the first PropertyValuesHolder object.

Parameters:
evaluatorthe evaluator to be used this animation
virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setRepeatCount ( int32_t  value) [virtual]

Sets how many times the animation should be repeated.

If the repeat count is 0, the animation is never repeated. If the repeat count is greater than 0 or INFINITE, the repeat mode will be taken into account. The repeat count is 0 by default.

Parameters:
valuethe number of times the animation should be repeated
virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setRepeatMode ( int32_t  value) [virtual]

Defines what this animation should do when it reaches the end.

This setting is applied only when the repeat count is either greater than 0 or INFINITE. Defaults to RESTART.

Parameters:
valueRESTART or REVERSE
virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setStartDelay ( int64_t  startDelay) [virtual]

The amount of time, in milliseconds, to delay starting the animation after start() is called.

Parameters:
startDelayThe amount of the delay, in milliseconds

Implements gaia::core::Animator.

virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::setValues ( int32_t  size,
PropertyValuesHolder *  values,
  ... 
) [virtual]

Sets the values, per property, being animated between.

This function is called internally by the constructors of ValueAnimator that take a list of values. But an ValueAnimator can be constructed without values and this method can be called to set the values manually instead.

Parameters:
sizeThe number of values.
valuesThe set of values, per property, being animated between.
virtual void gaia::core::ValueAnimator::start ( ) [virtual]

Starts this animation.

If the animation has a nonzero startDelay, the animation will start running after that delay elapses. A non-delayed animation will have its initial value(s) set immediately, followed by calls to IAnimatorListener::onAnimationStart(Animator*) for any listeners of this animator.

The animation started by calling this method will be run on the thread that called this method. This thread should have a Looper on it (a runtime exception will be thrown if this is not the case). Also, if the animation will animate properties of objects in the view hierarchy, then the calling thread should be the UI thread for that view hierarchy.

Reimplemented from gaia::core::Animator.

Reimplemented in gaia::core::ObjectAnimator.
